ranked_diseases.explanation: Classic presentation with infantile spasms, hypsarrhythmia on EEG, and developmental regression. The combination of these three features forms the diagnostic triad of West syndrome.
Early-onset epileptic encephalopathy with infantile spasms, multiple seizure types (focal tonic, focal myoclonic), severe developmental delay, and hypotonia. Common in females.
Early infantile epileptic encephalopathy with multiple seizure types including infantile spasms, focal seizures, severe developmental delay, and hypotonia.
Can present with infantile spasms, focal seizures, developmental delay, and encephalopathy. EEG abnormalities including hypsarrhythmia are common.
Common cause of infantile spasms with focal seizures, developmental delay, and hypotonia. Would need additional features like skin findings or brain imaging to confirm.
Similar presentation to TSC1 with infantile spasms, focal seizures, and developmental issues. Caused by TSC2 gene mutations.
X-linked disorder causing infantile spasms, severe developmental delay, and hypotonia. More common in males but can affect females.
Can present with early-onset seizures including focal seizures, encephalopathy, and developmental delay, though infantile spasms are less typical.
